}} 'Wilhelm Reich' (24 March 1897 â 3 November 1957) was an Austrian
psychoanalyst, a member of the second generation of psychoanalysts after Sigmund
Freud, and one of the most radical figures in the history of psychiatry. He was
the author of several influential books and essays, most notably [[Character
Analysis]] (1933), [[The Mass Psychology of Fascism]] (1933), and [[Die
SexualitÃ¤t im Kulturkampf|The Sexual Revolution]] (1936). That he was one of
the most radical figures in psychiatry, see [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,907256-
1,00.html Sheppard 1973].
*[http://books.google.com/books?id=lq8rwc61ae4C&pg=PA43 Danto 2007], p. 43:
"Wilhelm Reich, the second generation psychoanalyst perhaps most often
associated with political radicalism ..." *Turner 2011, p. 114: "[Reich's
mobile clinic was] perhaps the most radical, politically engaged psychoanalytic
enterprise to date." *For the publication and significance of The Mass
Psychology of Fascism and Character Analysis, see
[http://books.google.com/books?id=ddlMl4jJgh0C&pg=PA163 Sharaf 1994], pp.
163â164, 168. *For Character Analysis being an important contribution to
psychoanalytic theory, see:
:*[http://books.google.com/books?id=OcoQTQwTDu8C&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157 Young-Bruehl
:2008], p. 157: "Reich, a year and a half younger than Anna Freud, was the
:youngest instructor at the Training Institute, where his classes on
:psychoanalytic technique, later presented in a book called Character Analysis,
:were crucial to his whole group of contemporaries."
:*[http://books.google.com/books?id=uaFaiUZsFD4C&pg=PA35 Sterba 1982], p. 35:
:"This book [Character Analysis] serves even today as an excellent introduction
:to psychoanalytic technique. In my opinion, Reich's understanding of and
:technical approach to resistance prepared the way for Anna Freud's Ego and the
:Mechanisms of Defence (1936)."
:*[http://books.google.com/books?id=y6tfazvZU3gC&pg=PA105 Guntrip 1961], p. 105:
:"... the two important books of the middle 1930s, Character Analysis
:(1935) by Wilhelm Reich and The Ego and the Mechanisms of Defence (1936) by
:Anna Freud."
*For more on the influence of The Mass Psychology of Fascism, see
[http://www.jstor.org/stable/1024664 Kirkpatrick 1947],
[http://www.jstor.org/stable/2571947 Burgess 1947];
[http://www.jstor.org/stable/2771342 Bendix 1947]; and Turner 2011, p.
152. His work on character contributed to the development of Anna Freud's
The Ego and the Mechanisms of Defence (1936), and his idea of muscular armour â
the expression of the personality in the way the body moves â shaped innovations
such as body psychotherapy, Fritz Perls's Gestalt therapy, Alexander Lowen's
bioenergetic analysis, and Arthur Janov's primal therapy. His writing influenced
generations of intellectuals: during the 1968 student uprisings in Paris and
Berlin, students scrawled his name on walls and threw copies of The Mass
Psychology of Fascism at the police. For Anna Freud, see
[http://books.google.com/books?id=jtO7czidPeYC&pg=PA14 Bugental, Schneider and
Pierson 2001], p. 14: "Anna Freud's work on the ego and the mechanisms of
defense developed from Reich's early research (A. Freud, 1936/1948)." *For
Perls, Lowen and Janov, see
[http://books.google.com/books?id=ddlMl4jJgh0C&pg=PA4 Sharaf 1994], p. 4. *For
the students, see [http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20D15FE355F-
127A93CAA8178FD85F458785F9 Elkind, 18 April 1971]; and Turner 2011, pp.
13â14.

After graduating in medicine from the University of Vienna in 1922, Reich
studied neuropsychiatry under Julius Wagner-Jauregg and became deputy director
of the Vienna Ambulatorium, Freud's psychoanalytic outpatient
clinic. [http://books.google.com/books?id=ddlMl4jJgh0C&pg=PA66 Sharaf 1994],
p. 66; [http://books.google.com/books?id=lq8rwc61ae4C&pg=PA83 Danto 2007], p.
83. Described by Elizabeth Danto as a large man with a cantankerous style
who managed to look scruffy and elegant at the same time, he tried to reconcile
psychoanalysis with Marxism, arguing that neurosis is rooted in physical, sexual
and socio-economic conditions, and in particular in a lack of what he called
"orgastic potency." He visited patients in their homes to see how they lived,
and took to the streets in a mobile clinic, promoting adolescent sexuality and
the availability of contraceptives, abortion and divorce, a provocative message
in Catholic Austria. He said he wanted to "attack the neurosis by its prevention
rather than treatment." For Danto's description of Reich, see
[http://books.google.com/books?id=lq8rwc61ae4C&pg=PA118 Danto 2007], p. 118.
*That he visited patients in their homes, see
[http://books.google.com/books?id=EUw9AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA278 Grossinger 1982], p.
278, and Turner 2011, p. 82. *For the issues he promoted, see Turner 2011, p.
114, and [http://books.google.com/books?id=ddlMl4jJgh0C&pg=PA4 Sharaf 1994], pp.
4â5, 347, 481â482. *For orgastic potency and neurosis, see Corrington 2003, p.
75; and [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/23/books/review/adventures-in-the-
orgasmatron.html?pagewanted=all Turner, 23 September 2011]. *That he said he
wanted to "attack the neurosis by its prevention rather than treatment," see
Turner 2011, p. 114.

From the 1930s onwards he became an increasingly controversial figure; from 1932
until four years after his death no publisher other than his own published his
work. His promotion of sexual permissiveness disturbed the psychoanalytic
community and his associates on the political left, and his vegetotherapy, in
which he massaged his disrobed patients to dissolve their muscular armour,
violated the key taboos of psychoanalysis. For no publisher other than his
own publishing his work from 1932, see
[http://books.google.com/books?id=ddlMl4jJgh0C&pg=PA169 Sharaf 1994], p. 169;
for violating psychoanalytic taboos, pp. 234â235. *For his sexual permissiveness
disturbing certain groups, see
[http://books.google.com/books?id=lq8rwc61ae4C&pg=PA120 Danto 2007], p.
120. He moved to New York in 1939, in part to escape the Nazis, and
shortly after arriving there coined the term "orgone" â derived from "orgasm"
and "organism" â for a cosmic energy he said he had discovered, which he said
others referred to as God or ether. In 1940 he started building orgone
accumulators, devices that his patients sat inside to harness the reputed health
benefits, leading to newspaper stories about sex boxes that cured
cancer. [http://books.google.com/books?id=ddlMl4jJgh0C&pg=PA301 Sharaf
1994], pp. 301â306. *That Reich said God was the spiritual aspect of orgone and
the ether the physical, see
[http://books.google.com/books?id=ddlMl4jJgh0C&pg=PA472 Sharaf 1994], p. 472;
and Reich, Ether, God and Devil, pp. 39ff, 50.

Following two critical articles about him in The New Republic and Harper's, the
U.S. Food and Drug Administration obtained an injunction against the interstate
shipment of orgone accumulators and associated literature, believing they were
dealing with a "fraud of the first magnitude." For the articles, see
[http://www.harpers.org/archive/1947/04/0032908 Brady, April 1947]; and
[http://www.webcitation.org/68E1awEUD Brady, 26 May 1947]. *For "fraud of the
first magnitude," see [http://books.google.com/books?id=ddlMl4jJgh0C&pg=PA364
Sharaf 1994], p. 364. Charged with contempt in 1956 for having violated
the injunction, Reich was sentenced to two years in prison, and in June and
August that year over six tons of his publications were burned by order of the
court, one of the most notable examples of censorship in the history of the
United States. [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/496351/Wilhelm-
Reich "Wilhelm Reich"], Encyclopaedia Britannica, 2012: "From 1956 to 1960 many
of his writings and his equipment were seized and destroyed by FDA officials. In
the 21st century some considered this wholesale destruction to be one of the
most blatant examples of censorship in U.S. history." *That over six tons of
literature were burned, see Sharaf 1994, p. 460: some literature was burned in
June 1956, then six tons was burned in August. He died in jail of heart
failure just over a year later, days before he was due to apply for parole. [http://books.google.com/books?id=ddlMl4jJgh0C&pg=PA477 Sharaf
1994], p. 477.
categories: American people who died in prison custody
